risks.name: US-China Trade Tariff Reduction Agreement
risks.description: The United States and China have reached a trade agreement to significantly reduce tariffs. The US is lowering tariff rates on Chinese goods from 145% to 30%, while China is cutting tariffs on US goods from 125% to 10% for a 90-day period as negotiations continue. This represents a major de-escalation in the trade conflict that had previously seen retaliatory measures from both sides.
risks.marketImpact: Global markets experienced a significant positive reaction, with stocks soaring following the announcement.  The agreement has given markets a substantial boost, though analysts note that the remaining tariffs will still exert some inflationary pressure on the economy.  The 90-day timeframe suggests this is a temporary truce rather than a permanent resolution.  Sector impacts: Global Equities: Positive (Markets reacted positively to the news, with global stocks soaring and US equity markets making their first weekly gain in a month.
risks.source: Business Insider, JP Morgan, Investopedia, S&P Global

risks.name: Middle East Conflict Impacts Oil Markets
risks.description: Ongoing conflicts in the Middle East—including instability in Syria, tensions involving Iran, and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict—have heightened concerns over potential oil supply disruptions. While recent escalations, such as Iranian missile attacks and threats to regional oil infrastructure, have triggered the sharpest oil price rise in two years, overall market reaction has been more muted than in previous crises. Analysts note that the risk premium in oil prices has increased, but actual supply disruptions remain limited so far, with OPEC+ production and global oversupply helping to stabilize prices. The situation remains fluid, with the potential for further volatility if the conflict widens or directly impacts major oil producers.
risks.marketImpact: Brent crude futures spiked by approximately 5% in the immediate aftermath of recent escalations, marking the largest single-week gain in two years, before retracing some gains as fears of direct supply disruption eased.  Energy sector equities, such as the S&P 500 Energy Index, outperformed broader indices, while airlines and transport stocks faced pressure due to higher fuel costs.  Global equity markets experienced increased volatility, with the MSCI World Index declining by around 1. 2% over the past week.

risks.name: European Central Bank Policy Meeting
risks.description: On May 13, 2025, the European Central Bank (ECB) held its scheduled policy meeting, focusing on ongoing inflation concerns and the economic growth outlook for the eurozone. The ECB has recently taken a dovish stance, lowering its key interest rates by 25 basis points in both March and April 2025, with the main refinancing rate now at 2.4%, the marginal lending facility at 2.65%, and the deposit facility at 2.25%. Policymakers noted that while headline inflation is projected to average 2.3% in 2025, underlying inflation is expected to gradually converge to the ECB’s 2% target by 2027, with wage growth moderating and energy prices remaining a key variable. The meeting reaffirmed the ECB’s commitment to supporting growth while remaining vigilant on inflation dynamics.
risks.marketImpact: Eurozone equity indices such as the Euro Stoxx 50 and DAX showed modest gains of 0. 4–0. 7% following the meeting, reflecting investor optimism over continued monetary support.  The euro weakened slightly against the US dollar, dropping 0.

risks.name: Major Cyber Attack Affects Financial Institutions
risks.description: In April-May 2025, multiple financial institutions experienced sophisticated cyber attacks, including a significant breach at the Treasury Department's Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) that compromised sensitive financial institution data. DBS Group and Bank of China (Singapore) were affected by a ransomware attack on their third-party data vendor Toppan Next Tech, potentially exposing thousands of client statements and customer information. These incidents represent part of a broader pattern of escalating cyber threats targeting the financial sector globally.
risks.marketImpact: The cyber attacks have disrupted online banking services and compromised sensitive financial data, particularly affecting retail banking operations.  DBS Group reported approximately 8,200 client statements were potentially exposed, mainly affecting its trading platform DBS Vickers and cashline loan accounts.  Bank of China disclosed data from around 3,000 customers were potentially compromised, including names, addresses, and loan account numbers.  Sector impacts: Banking: Negative (DBS Group and Bank of China (Singapore) reported potential compromise of approximately 11,200 combined customer records through a third-party vendor breach.

risks.name: Federal Reserve Holds Interest Rates Steady at May 2025 Meeting
risks.description: The Federal Reserve maintained its federal funds rate at 4.25-4.50% during its May 7, 2025 meeting, marking the third consecutive meeting with unchanged rates. The Fed noted increased economic uncertainty, highlighting risks to both unemployment and inflation while adopting a wait-and-see approach amid concerns about President Trump's tariffs potentially driving inflation and slowing economic growth.
risks.marketImpact: Financial markets have been closely monitoring the Fed's stance as it balances inflation concerns against economic growth prospects.  The decision to maintain rates steady while acknowledging increased economic uncertainty has created a cautious environment for investors, particularly in rate-sensitive sectors.  Markets are now pricing in a more gradual approach to any future rate adjustments as the Fed assesses incoming economic data.
